channel.title: Home on Columbia Psychology Scientific Computing
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Columbia Psychology Scientific Computing

item.title: Descriptives
item.description: Return home Goals for this tutorial: 0. Open dataset and load package 1. Familiarize yourself with the data 2. Selecting relevant variables 3. Basic Descriptives Summarizing data 4. Grouping data 5. Extra: Working with a long dataset How many unique subjects are in the data Make sure you know how many trials there were per subj. Combine summary statistics with the full data frame 6.

item.title: Getting your data ready for analysis
item.description: Goals of this lesson Install Packages Getting your Data into R Entering data directly Reading data into R Inspecting your data How is your data frame structured? Brief intro to tidyverse Rename a variable Check for missing data Check for correct values Filtering data Getting ready for analysis Recoding variables Calculating new variables Combining data from multiple sources Shaping data Saving your work Data Challenge!

item.title: License
item.description: License Instructional Material All CU Psych Computing instructional material is made available under the Creative Commons Attribution license. The following is a human-readable summary of (and not a substitute for) the full legal text of the CC BY 4.0 license. You are free: to Share—copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format to Adapt—remix, transform, and build upon the material for any purpose, even commercially.

item.title: Meetings
item.description: Meetings Come and learn with us at one of our meetings! Topics span various early-intermediate to advanced strategies for asking psychological research questions using scientific computing tools. Upcoming To be announced. Past Under construction! Documentation of past meetings will be added soon.

item.title: Modeling
item.description: Basics for modeling in R Functions: Basic models Syntax: Basic model formula To add multiple factors Interactions Output of models Linear models Anova Visualizing models Advanced models Welcome to the lesson on modeling in R! Goals: 1. Learn about functions and syntax for models in R 2. Practice examples of different model types 3. Understand how to obtain model results in R

item.title: Plotting Tutorial Using ggplot2!
item.description: Return home 0: What is this tutorial? What’s ggplot2? 1: First Load Tidyverse, which includes ggplot2! 2: Load in Sample Data (NHANES) 3: Scatter Plot & Basic ggplot Syntax 3a: Histograms with ggplot 4: Dot Plot Organized by Grouping Factor 4a: Visualizing Distributions with Violin Plots 5: Summary Plots 6: Fitting Lines To The Data 7: Titles, Axis Labels 7: Facetting 8: Color 9: Themes 10: Saving To Files 11: Heatmaps 12: Basic Time Series Plot 13: Final Points Return home Click here to return to the main CU psychology R tutorials page.

item.title: Programming, pt 0
item.description: Working with RStudio Installing R & RStudio Getting oriented to the RStudio window R project files Console window Editor window Environment/history window Files/pkgs/help window Installing and loading packages Working directories, file paths, etc The working directory File paths Absolute file paths Relative file paths Special file path keywords Reading data into R Generating a file path using here() Reading the data into R Loading the file as an R object Welcome to the CU Psychology Scientific Computing workshop!

item.title: Programming, pt 1
item.description: Variables Data types Numeric data Arithmetic operators Logical data Character data Dataframe columns have data types too Data structures Data frames Working with dataframe columns Summarizing dataframe columns Indexing into dataframes Vectors Indexing into vectors Data types pt 2 Factor data Non-data data Welcome (back) to the CU Psychology Scientific Computing Workshop! As a reminder, the documents for the introduction to programming cover the following:

item.title: Programming, pt 2
item.description: Pseudocode Relational operators Filtering data Operating on filtered data Logical operators Conditional operators Functions Anatomy of a function Writing your own function Getting assistance On your own The help docs The internet Asking someone else How to ask Welcome (back) to the CU Psychology Scientific Computing workshop! As a reminder, the documents for the introduction to programming cover the following:

item.title: Resources
item.description: Resources Columbia-Specific Resources Columbia Psychology scientific computing users Slack group) Full, Freestanding General-Use R Tutorials Mainly base R tutorials Cookbook for R: Basics of data cleaning, analysis and graphing Tidyverse tutorials Hadley Wickham’s R for Data Science online textbook Michael C. Frank’s psychology-specific tidyverse tutorial, adapted from R for Data Science Syllabi for courses taught in R You can work along with these; course materials should be linked in the syllabi.

item.title: Tidy walkthrough, part 1
item.description: Goals for this vignette Please keep in mind! Quick cheat-list of key functions from various pkgs Brief intro to the pipe Initializing fake data Loading data Visually inspecting data Subsetting data Subsetting by column Subsetting by row Logical subsetting Subsetting rows by position Getting only unique/un-duplicated rows Subsetting random rows Subsetting by row and column simultaneously Manipulating data Creating/modifying columns Nice helpers Calculating summary statistics Special versions of summarize() Grouping Mutating grouped data Summarizing grouped data When to ungroup your df Creating new rows Repeating existing rows Completing combinations of grouping variables Reshaping data From wide to long Pivot-longering multiple distinct variables at once From long to wide Pivot-widering multiple distinct variables at once Coming up in part 2 Goals for this vignette Demonstrate (what I think are) key first-level features of the tidyverse Illustrate psychology use cases for tidyverse functions Hopefully convince you to join the cult of tidy We shall do this by walking through various use cases you might encounter with your data.

item.title: Tidy walkthrough, part 2
item.description: Goals for this vignette Quick cheat-list of key functions from various pkgs Initializing fake data Joining dfs Nested dfs A brief (re)view of lists Lists as df columns A df with a list-column still behaves like a df, mostly df-ception: df list-columns that contain other dfs Vectorizing to the high heavens Vectorizing: it’s like a for loop, but not Tidy vectorizing Intro to map() Special versions of map() Using map() on list-columns inside a df When not to vectorize Working with model objects en masse Fitting a whole lotta models Extracting model coefficients Plotting data Goals for this vignette Hello (again)!

item.title: Who We Are
item.description: Who We Are 2020 - 2021 Graduate Methods Support Advisors Emily Nakkawita Research interests: how goal pursuit processes differ based on individuals’ unique motivational orientations Method specialties: surveys, web-based response latency tasks Tool/language specialties: R, generating manuscripts with Papaja, Javascript/HTML customization in Qualtrics, M-Turk, Prolific Favorite NYC neighborhood: Park Slope Office hours: To be announced Hannah Tarder-Stoll Research interests: how memory is flexibly used to predict future events at different timescales Method specialties: cognitive tasks (in-person and web-based), neuroimaging, virtual reality Tool/language specialties: R, Python, Unity, Inquisit Favorite NYC neighborhood: Astoria Office hours: To be announced Contributors to Scientific Computing Workshop The lesson materials for the introductory workshop are the evolving product of several contributors, past and present, from the Columbia University psychology department.

item.title: Workshop
item.description: Fall 2020 Workshop Instructors: Paul A. Bloom, Emily Nakkawita, Jonathan Nicholas, Matt Siegelman, Hannah Tarder-Stoll, Monica Thieu General Information This workshop develops and teaches the scientific computing skills needed to conduct psychological research. Its target audience is researchers who have little to no prior computational experience, and its lessons are psychology-specific, building on learners’ existing knowledge to enable them to quickly apply skills learned to their own research.
